original_title: Sri Lanka drug prices cut 16-pct from June 15: Minister
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Prices of all medicines registered with Sri Lanka’s National Medicine Regulatory Authority will be reduced by 16 percent from June 15 onwards, passing the benefit of the rupee appreciation to the general public, Minister of Health Keheliya Rambukwella said.

“From June 15,203, given the encouraging appreciation of the rupee against the US dollar, there’ll be a 16% reduction in NMRA registered drugs which are regulated by a price control,” Minister Rambukwella in a twitter.com message said.
“This was decided after extensive discussions with the relevant authorities.”

NMRA approved two price hike for medicines in 2022 after importers requested the regulator to increase the prices following a sudden devaluation of the rupee after the central bank let the rupee float.
Due to depletion of foreign exchange in the country, importers have been struggling to open letters of credit from commercial banks from mid-February onwards.

Sri Lanka’s rupee has so far appreciated from around 360 to the US dollar to below 300 to the US dollar in 2023 amid complementary money and exchange policies of the central bank which is creating a virtuous policy cycle.(Colombo/June 05/2023)
